questions.stem: When should you use a period after an abbreviation at the end of a sentence?

options.label: Always use two periods (one for abbreviation, one for sentence)
Use only one period (it serves both purposes)
It depends on the type of abbreviation

questions.rationale: Use only one period at the end of a sentence, even after abbreviations. The single period serves both purposes.

questions.stem: Click on the error in this sentence:
questions.rationale: Only one period is needed at the end of a sentence, even after an abbreviation like 'p.m.'

questions.stem: Which sentence correctly uses periods?

options.label: Dr Smith will attend the meeting.
Dr. Smith will attend the meeting.
Dr Smith will attend the meeting
Dr. Smith will attend the meeting

questions.rationale: Use periods with courtesy titles like 'Dr.' and end declarative sentences with periods.

questions.stem: Please submit your report by Friday____
questions.rationale: Imperative sentences (commands or requests) end with periods.

questions.stem: Should headings and titles end with periods?

options.label: Only if they are complete sentences

questions.rationale: Headings and titles do not end with periods, regardless of their length or format.

questions.stem: Which sentence correctly uses the Oxford comma?

options.label: We need pens, paper and ink.
We need pens, paper, and ink.
We need pens paper and ink.
We need pens; paper; and ink.

questions.rationale: Canadian style uses the Oxford comma (serial comma) before 'and' in a series: pens, paper, and ink.

questions.stem: When do you use a comma before a coordinating conjunction?
questions.rationale: Use a comma before coordinating conjunctions (and, but, or, nor, for, so, yet) when they connect two independent clauses.

questions.stem: Click on the missing comma in this sentence:
questions.text: After the meeting we will discuss the results.
questions.rationale: Use a comma after introductory elements: 'After the meeting, we will discuss the results.'

questions.stem: Which sentence correctly punctuates the non-restrictive clause?

options.label: My brother who lives in Toronto is visiting.
My brother, who lives in Toronto, is visiting.
My brother who lives in Toronto; is visiting.
My brother: who lives in Toronto is visiting.

questions.rationale: Non-restrictive clauses (additional information) are set off with commas. If you have only one brother, the clause is non-restrictive.

questions.stem: What is a comma splice?

options.label: Using too many commas in one sentence
Joining two independent clauses with only a comma
Forgetting to use commas in a series

questions.rationale: A comma splice incorrectly joins two independent clauses with only a comma. Use a semicolon, period, or add a coordinating conjunction.

questions.stem: When should you use a semicolon?

options.label: To separate items in any list

questions.rationale: Semicolons connect closely related independent clauses that could stand alone as sentences.

questions.stem: Which sentence correctly uses a semicolon?

options.label: The project is due tomorrow; I'll work late tonight.
Although it was raining; we went for a walk.
We need; pens, paper, and ink.

questions.rationale: The first option correctly connects two independent clauses. The others incorrectly use semicolons with dependent clauses or in lists.

questions.stem: The weather was terrible______ however, we still went hiking.
questions.rationale: Use a semicolon before transitional expressions like 'however' when they connect independent clauses.

questions.stem: When should you use semicolons in lists?

options.label: In all lists with more than two items

questions.rationale: Use semicolons to separate items in lists when the items themselves contain commas, for clarity.

questions.stem: What's the semicolon test?

options.label: If you can replace it with a comma, it's correct
If you can replace it with a period and make two complete sentences, it's correct
If it comes before 'and', it's correct
If it's in the middle of a sentence, it's correct

questions.rationale: The semicolon test: if you can replace the semicolon with a period and create two grammatically complete sentences, you're using it correctly.

questions.stem: What must come before a colon?

options.label: A complete thought or independent clause

questions.rationale: A colon must be preceded by a complete thought or independent clause. Don't use colons after incomplete thoughts.

questions.stem: Which sentence correctly uses a colon?

options.label: The team includes: John, Mary, and Bob.
The team includes the following members: John, Mary, and Bob.
The team: includes John, Mary, and Bob.
The team includes John: Mary: and Bob.

questions.rationale: The colon must follow a complete thought. 'The team includes' is incomplete, but 'The team includes the following members' is complete.

questions.stem: When do you capitalize after a colon?

options.label: When introducing a complete sentence or formal quotation

questions.rationale: Capitalize after a colon when introducing a complete sentence or formal quotation. Use lowercase for lists or phrases.

questions.stem: The deadline was missed for one reason______ poor planning.
questions.rationale: Use a colon to introduce an explanation or elaboration on the preceding complete thought.

questions.stem: In which context do you NOT typically use colons?
questions.rationale: Colons are not used between adjectives and nouns. They're used in time, ratios, quotations, lists, and formal salutations.

questions.stem: How do you form the possessive of a singular noun ending in 's'?
questions.rationale: For singular nouns ending in 's', add 's to form the possessive: James's book, the boss's office.

questions.stem: Which is correct?
questions.rationale: 'It's' is a contraction meaning 'it is.' 'Its' (no apostrophe) is the possessive pronoun.

questions.stem: How do you show possession for a plural noun ending in 's'?
questions.rationale: For plural nouns ending in 's', add only an apostrophe: the workers' union, the cats' toys.

questions.stem: Click on the incorrect apostrophe in this sentence:
questions.text: The decision is your's to make.
questions.rationale: Possessive pronouns (yours, hers, ours, theirs) never take apostrophes.

questions.stem: Which sentence correctly uses apostrophes?
questions.rationale: Don't use apostrophes for simple plurals. '1990s' is just a plural, not possessive.

questions.stem: What is the difference between em dashes and en dashes?

options.label: Em dashes are longer and used for emphasis; en dashes are shorter and used for ranges
Em dashes are shorter and used for ranges; en dashes are longer and used for emphasis
They are the same thing with different names
Em dashes are for formal writing; en dashes are for informal writing

questions.rationale: Em dashes (—) are longer and used for emphasis or breaks in thought. En dashes (–) are shorter and used for ranges or connections.

questions.stem: Which sentence correctly uses an em dash?

options.label: The solution is simple — work harder.
The meeting is at 9:00 a.m. — 5:00 p.m.
This is a cost — benefit analysis.

questions.rationale: Em dashes are used for emphasis or to set off explanatory information. En dashes are used for ranges and connections.

questions.stem: Which uses an en dash correctly?

options.label: The team—our best performers—will handle this.
I think we should—wait, never mind.

questions.rationale: En dashes connect equal elements like city pairs, while em dashes are used for emphasis or interruptions.

questions.stem: The office hours are 9:00 a.m.____5:00 p.m.
questions.rationale: Use an en dash (or hyphen if en dash unavailable) for time ranges.

questions.stem: How should you use em dashes in Canadian style?

options.label: With spaces around them — like this
Only at the end of sentences—

questions.rationale: In Canadian style, em dashes have no spaces around them—they connect directly to the surrounding text.
